Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CC-NIE Integration: Developing Applications with Networking Capabilities via End-to-End SDN (DANCES)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The DANCES project team of network engineers, application developers, and research scientists is implementing a software-defined networking (SDN)-enabled end-to-end environment to optimize support for scientific data transfer. DANCES accomplishes this optimization by integrating high performance computing job scheduling, network control capabilities offered by SDN along with data movement applications in an end-to-end network infrastructure. This integration provides access to control mechanisms for managing network bandwidth. The control of network resources enabled by SDN enhances application stability, predictability and performance, thereby improving overall network utilization. Motivation for the DANCES project is to apply the advantages of advanced network services to the problem of congested metropolitan and campus networks. DANCES uses XSEDENet across Internet2 in conjunction with OpenFlow-enabled network switches installed at the collaborating sites as the end-to-end hardware and software substrate.

Knowledge gained through DANCES is being disseminated through educational programs offered by the participating institutions and at existing community workshops, meetings, and conferences. The insights and experience obtained through DANCES will promote a better understanding of the technical requirements for supporting end-to-end SDN across wide area and campus cyberinfrastructure. The resulting SDN-enabled applications will make the request and configuration of high bandwidth connections easily accessible to end users and improve network performance and predictability for supporting a wide range of applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Goal of the project

Due to the rapidly increasing volume of biological data from sequencing, imaging, and other technologies, data processing needs in the Life Sciences are now on par with physical, mathematical, and engineering disciplines. Because of our experience with data intensive biology through the NSF funded Galaxy project, we were chosen to participate in the DANCES project, which is implementing a software-defined networking (SDN)-enabled end-to-end environment to optimize support for scientific data transfer. To this end our goal was to enable efficient and reliable data transfer between major supercomputing centers within the framework of the Galaxy project (http://galaxyproject.org). The Galaxy project started in 2005 to create a system enabling biologists without informatics expertise to perform computational analysis through the Internet. Existing analysis tools are defined in Galaxy with wrappers that describe tool behavior and which are then used to generate a consistent user interface. Multi-step analyses can be performed by running tools in succession, and Galaxy preserves the complete provenance of each analysis step in a history. By bridging the gap between tool developers and researchers, Galaxy helps both constituencies accelerate their research. 

Intellectial merit

NSF has funded a number of high performnace computational (HPC) resources througout the United States. These resorces have been traditionally used within domains of physical and mathematical sciences as well as engineering. Rapid expansion of data generation capability in Life Sciences has made these resources extremeley valuable for life sciences research. However, the distributed nature of data generation in life sciences, potential data privacy issues, and the sheer size of the data created a number of challenges. The intellectiul merit of our work was in prototyping and testing approaches for effective and robust transfer of these datasets across geographically distributed HPC facilities. 

Broader Impact

Enabling utilization of existing HPC resources by Life Sciencers community will significantly improve data-to-analysis bottleneck that is currently plaguing the field. It will also enable effecting utilization of already existing resources. The figure attached to this document shows how current Galaxy infrastructure connects widely distributed NSF-funded HPC centers including Pittsburgh Supercomuting Center (PCS), Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC), and JetSream resource at Indiana University (IU). To the best of our knowldge this is the only publc, freely accessible resourse of its kind.
